  • Ugandan Stages: Dense rainforests and red clay roads became nearly impassable after the rains.

Only 7 crews completed the rally. The winners, Nowicki and Cliff in their Peugeot 404, drove conservatively and strategically, avoiding disaster where faster competitors faltered.

events.title: 1963 Tulip Rally (Rally van Nederland)

events.title: 1963 Acropolis Rally

cars.name: Mini Cooper S

cars.name: Audi Quattro / Sport Quattro / S1 E2

The 131 Abarth was forgiving and predictable â€” ideal for rough gravel rallies where durability and consistent pace were essential. The Fiat 131 Abarth capped off the era of rear-wheel-drive dominance with grit and grace. As one of the last true sedan-based world champions, it remains a symbol of clever engineering and rugged charm â€” a fan favorite in historic rallies to this day.

cars.name: Ford Escort RS1800 Mk2
cars.bio: The Ford Escort RS1800 Mk2 carried over its rally dominance into the early 1980s, remaining a gravel weapon of choice for top-tier drivers and privateers even as the sport began transitioning toward AWD and Group B machines.

The Ford Escort RS1800 Mk2 was one of the most successful rally cars of the late 1970s, and its legacy extended into the early 1980s as it continued to score wins and podiums well past its Group 4 heyday. With its robust BDA engine, lightweight shell, and near-perfect balance on gravel, the Mk2 Escort remained a favorite of skilled privateers and legendary drivers alike. Even as Group B began reshaping rally car design, the RS1800 proved that well-sorted rear-wheel-drive machinery still had a place â€” particularly on traditional forest stages and in national-level competition.

  • Engine: 2.0L Cosworth BDA inline-4
  • Power Output: ~240 hp (in full rally spec)
  • Drivetrain: Rear-wheel drive
  • Weight: ~950 kg (2,094 lbs)
  • Layout: Front-engine, short-wheelbase coupe

Simple, tough, and tunable â€” the RS1800â€™s winning formula came from years of refinement and rally-proven components. Its predictable handling and torque-rich powerband made it a weapon on loose surfaces long after its official factory career ended.

  • 1980 Rally Portugal: Hannu Mikkola wins in the RS1800, defeating newer machinery.

The Escort Mk2 was often the best RWD car in events with mixed or loose surfaces. Even as factory teams moved on to more exotic machinery, the Escort remained a winning tool in the hands of privateers across Europe and beyond.

With sharp turn-in, excellent throttle balance, and forgiving dynamics, the RS1800 was a driverâ€™s car through and through. The Mk2 Escort RS1800 is a rally icon â€” a car that defined an era and remained relevant well into the 1980s. cars.name: Ford RS200
cars.bio: The Ford RS200 was a purpose-built Group B rally car that combined a mid-engine layout, advanced four-wheel drive, and striking design â€” a technical marvel held back by late development and the abrupt end of its era.

The Ford RS200 was Fordâ€™s long-awaited response to the rising firepower of Group B. Designed entirely from scratch, the RS200 featured a mid-mounted turbocharged engine and sophisticated four-wheel-drive system housed within a lightweight composite shell. The RS200 was one of the most balanced Group B cars ever built. With minimal understeer, quick turn-in, and a perfectly centered engine layout, it felt composed on a wide range of surfaces. The Ford RS200 is the quintessential â€˜what if?â€™ car of Group B. Built with vision and cutting-edge engineering, it never had the chance to prove itself on the world stage. Today, RS200s are prized in historic motorsport, rallycross, and car collections, where they continue to thrill with a mix of precision, rawness, and unfulfilled destiny.

cars.name: Ford Sierra RS Cosworth / 4x4

The rear-wheel-drive Sierra Cosworth was thrilling but tail-happy, requiring skilled throttle control and bravery in high-speed corners. The Ford Sierra RS Cosworth became an icon â€” not just in rallying, but in wider car culture. Its massive rear wing, turbo surge, and motorsport pedigree made it a fan favorite. The 1980s Cosworths remain among the most cherished performance cars of their time, bridging the analog era with turbocharged technology.

cars.name: Lancia 037 Rally

The 037â€™s supercharged setup gave it immediate throttle response, making it ideal for twisty tarmac stages. Its lightweight construction and balanced chassis gave it exceptional handling precision, though it struggled in loose or wet conditions compared to 4WD rivals.

Though it lacked consistency on gravel and snow, the 037 was a tarmac specialist. Its success in the early Group B years showcased how a lightweight, well-engineered RWD car could still compete at the highest level â€” if only briefly.

Precise, sharp, and brutally honest â€” the 037 demanded technique and bravery. The Lancia 037 Rally is a symbol of defiance in motorsport history â€” the last RWD champion in an age overtaken by all-wheel drive. Its striking silhouette, supercharger whine, and underdog success have made it a cult favorite. Revered by purists and collectors alike, the 037 remains one of the most beautifully engineered and emotionally charged rally cars of the 1980s.

cars.name: Lancia Delta HF 4WD / Integrale / 16v
cars.bio: The Lancia Delta HF 4WD and its Integrale evolutions became the benchmark of Group A rallying, dominating the WRC with unmatched consistency, speed, and adaptability starting in 1987.

After Group Bâ€™s abrupt cancellation, Lancia quickly pivoted to Group A regulations with the Delta HF 4WD â€” a turbocharged, four-wheel-drive variant of their compact road car. From 1987 to 1989, no team came close to matching the Deltaâ€™s blend of performance, reliability, and versatility across all surfaces.

The Lancia Delta Integrale is the most successful rally car in WRC history, and its dominance began in the late 1980s. It ushered in the golden age of Group A rallying and inspired a generation of turbocharged AWD performance cars â€” leaving a legacy that continues to influence rally design and culture decades later.

cars.name: Lancia Delta S4
cars.bio: The Lancia Delta S4 was a terrifyingly fast Group B machine that pushed the boundaries of rally car design with its twincharged engine, all-wheel drive, and explosive performance, becoming both a legend and a symbol of the categoryâ€™s excess.

In just a handful of WRC appearances, the S4 proved blisteringly fast, but its terrifying performance and tragic accident at the 1986 Tour de Corse also contributed to the end of Group B entirely.

Violent, demanding, and unmatched in raw power â€” the Delta S4 was not for the faint of heart. It launched out of corners with savage grip and had so much acceleration that co-drivers often struggled to keep pace. ğŸ”§ Legacy & Cultural Impact

The Lancia Delta S4 has become a legend of rally folklore â€” a symbol of both Group Bâ€™s highest peak and its darkest hour. Its insane performance, tragic story, and rarity have made it one of the most revered rally cars of all time. It is remembered as a turning point in the sport, where innovation outpaced safety, and motorsport had to pause and reset.

cars.name: MG Metro 6R4

The 6R4 was known for its razor-sharp handling and immediate engine response. The MG Metro 6R4 is one of the most beloved oddballs of the Group B era. Though it never reached the top step of the WRC podium, its distinct character, British engineering roots, and extended career in rallycross earned it a devoted following. cars.name: Mazda 323 GTX
cars.bio: The Mazda 323 GTX was a compact, turbocharged Group A contender that proved surprisingly capable in harsh endurance rallies, particularly in Africa, where its durability and traction made it a tough underdog.

The 323 GTX was compact, responsive, and easy to control. Its modest power output made it accessible to drive at the limit without becoming overwhelming. The Mazda 323 GTX may not have redefined rallying, but it carved out a respected legacy as a dependable Group A challenger. Its Safari and Swedish victories proved Mazda could compete with the best. Today, it remains a cult classic among rally fans and a reminder that toughness and clever engineering can still triumph in motorsportâ€™s harshest arenas.

cars.name: Nissan 240RS

The 240RS required grit and endurance from its drivers. It wasnâ€™t agile or quick off the line, but it handled rough terrain well and delivered predictable, steady handling. The Nissan 240RS is a Group B anomaly â€” a naturally aspirated RWD car that earned respect not by breaking speed records, but by refusing to break down. cars.name: Opel Ascona 400

The Opel Ascona 400 is remembered as the last of a dying breed â€” a RWD rally champion standing tall just before Group B changed the game. cars.name: Peugeot 205 Turbo 16 / Evo 2

cars.name: Ford Escort RS Cosworth
